content.title: Understanding Gargoyle Gecko Care
content.content: Gargoyle geckos are 6-8 inch arboreal lizards native to the tropical rainforests of New Caledonia. Known for their manageable size, simple care requirements, and tolerance toward humans, they make excellent first-time reptiles with proper husbandry.
Gargoyle geckos (Rhacodactylus auriculatus) are medium-sized arboreal lizards with distinctive features that make them popular in the reptile hobby.

content.text: Physical Characteristics:

items: Size: 6-8 inches total length when fully grown
Coloration: Range from cream to dark brown with variety of patterns depending on morph
Unique Features: Wide toes with adhesive toe pads allow climbing smooth surfaces; distinctive fringe runs from above eyes down back
Build: Stockier than crested geckos with more prominent cranial bumps (resembling gargoyle horns)
Tail: Prehensile tail aids in climbing; can drop if threatened but does NOT regenerate

content.text: Natural Habitat:

items: Geographic Range: Native to New Caledonia (islands of Grande Terre and Isle of Pines)
Environment: Tropical rainforest habitat with high humidity and moderate temperatures
Lifestyle: Arboreal (tree-dwelling) - found among trees, vines, and forest canopy
Climate: Warm and humid year-round with cooler nights
Activity Pattern: Crepuscular (most active at sunset and during night) with exceptional night vision

rows: Easy - Ideal for first-time reptile keepers
15-20 years (may live longer with excellent care)
Generally docile and tolerant of handling
Arboreal - tall enclosures preferred (taller than wide)
Omnivore - Crested gecko diet powder + live insects
Not recommended for beginners - males must never be housed together

content.content: Gargoyle geckos are exceptional beginner reptiles due to their manageable size, simple care requirements, docile nature, and 15-20 year lifespan. Unlike crested geckos, gargoyles can be more food-motivated and typically tolerate handling well.
Meeting these core requirements ensures your gargoyle gecko thrives physically and behaviorally.

rows: Provides adequate climbing space and temperature gradient
12" Arcadia T8 6% or Zoo Med T8 ReptiSun 5.0, UVI 1.0-2.0
Supports vitamin D3 synthesis and natural behavior (can survive without but do best with it)
Maintains hydration and supports healthy shedding
Raises humidity and provides drinking water
Crested gecko diet + multiple feeder insect types
Branches, vines, foliage at all levels
Allows arboreal behavior and proper thermoregulation

content.content: Cohabitation Warning: While some experienced keepers successfully house multiple females or one male with females, this is NOT recommended for beginners. Males will fight aggressively and must NEVER be housed together. Cohabitation requires larger enclosures and careful monitoring for aggression, injuries, and resource guarding.
Enrichment stimulates natural arboreal behaviors and prevents stress. Gargoyle geckos need vertical climbing opportunities, secure resting spots at multiple heights, and environmental complexity.

content.text: Vertical Climbing Structures:

items: Branches: Horizontal and diagonal branches at multiple heights (top, middle, bottom thirds of enclosure). Use bamboo, mopani wood, or cork branches
Vines: Flexible vines create pathways between branches and add visual barriers. Arrange in crisscross patterns for variety
Live or Artificial Plants: Pothos, bromeliads, ferns, or quality artificial foliage provide cover and climbing surfaces
Cork Bark: Cork rounds or flats leaned at angles create varied climbing surfaces
Vertical Utilization: Ensure gecko can access all levels (top, middle, bottom) via connected pathways

content.text: Resting & Security Areas:

items: Foliage Clusters: Dense areas of leaves at multiple heights provide secure sleeping spots during day
Arboreal Hides: Magnetic cork bark hides or bamboo tubes attached to walls offer secure elevated resting areas
Spanish Moss: Drape over branches to create soft, concealing texture
Multiple Options: Provide 3-4 potential sleeping areas at different heights and temperatures
Visual Barriers: Foliage should break line of sight across enclosure - reduces stress from feeling exposed

content.text: Environmental Complexity:

items: Live Plants: Pothos, snake plants, bromeliads, and ferns thrive in humid enclosures; add realism and maintain humidity
Feeding Ledges: Magnetic feeding ledges at mid-height allow natural elevated feeding behavior
Substrate Depth: 2-4 inches of moisture-retentive substrate provides cushion if gecko falls and stabilizes humidity
Leaf Litter: Add layer of leaf litter on substrate for naturalistic appearance and isopod/springtail habitat (if bioactive)
Décor Rotation: Rearrange 1-2 items monthly for novel exploration without excessive stress

content.content: Key Enrichment Principle: Gargoyle geckos are arboreal and spend 80-90% of time off the ground. Focus on vertical space utilization with interconnected climbing pathways at multiple heights rather than floor space decorations.
Understanding natural gargoyle gecko behavior helps identify normal activity versus potential welfare concerns.

rows: Active at sunset/dusk and throughout night; sleeps during day hidden in foliage
Constant daytime activity or never emerging at night may indicate stress or temperature issues
Regularly climbs walls, branches, and vines; explores all levels of enclosure
Staying only at bottom of enclosure suggests temps too warm at top OR lack of climbing confidence (injury/illness)
Enthusiastic eating of CGD and insects; may lick CGD directly from cup or gecko's face
Refusing food 2+ weeks (outside breeding season) suggests illness or husbandry issues
Every 4-6 weeks depending on age and growth rate
Stuck shed (especially on toes/tail) indicates humidity too low or dehydration
Occasional chirps, barks, or squeaks when startled, during handling, or territorial displays
Constant vocalizations or distress calls indicate extreme stress or pain
Intact prehensile tail used for gripping branches
Dropped tail indicates severe stress or improper handling (does NOT regenerate unlike crested geckos)
Darker colors at night (fired up) when active; paler during day when resting
Consistently pale or dark regardless of time suggests stress or illness
Perched on branch or hidden in foliage during day, body relaxed
Constantly on ground, tense body posture, or labored breathing indicates problems

content.content: Tail Autonomy: Unlike crested geckos whose tails regenerate, gargoyle gecko tails do NOT grow back after dropping. Once lost, the tail is permanently gone. Avoid grabbing or restraining gecko by tail, and minimize stress to prevent tail drops.
Recognizing early signs of welfare problems allows quick intervention before conditions become serious.

rows: Tremors, weak limbs, kinked tail, soft jaw, difficulty climbing
Insufficient UVB, improper diet (too much fruit, not enough CGD), lack of calcium supplementation
Provide UVB (UVI 1.0-2.0), feed quality CGD as staple, dust insects with calcium powder
Sunken eyes, wrinkled skin, lethargy, stuck shed
Insufficient misting, low humidity (<60%), no water droplets to lick
Mist twice daily (morning/evening), maintain 60-80% humidity, provide water dish
Retained skin on toes, tail, or body after shedding
Humidity too low (<60%), insufficient misting, dehydration
Maintain 60-80% humidity, mist twice daily, provide humid retreat in foliage
Open-mouth breathing, mucus bubbles, wheezing, lethargy
Temperatures too cool (<70F at night), humidity too HIGH (>85% constantly) with poor ventilation
Maintain proper temps (82-85F basking), ensure adequate ventilation, avoid over-misting
Tail hangs limp, gecko cannot use tail for gripping
Calcium deficiency, improper diet, genetic factors
Provide UVB, feed quality CGD, supplement insects, consult vet for severe cases
Tail dropped (clean break at tail base), no regeneration
Excessive handling, grabbing tail, stress, cohabitation aggression
Handle gently (never grab tail), reduce stress, house individually
Excessively plump body, fat deposits at base of tail/limbs, difficulty climbing
Overfeeding (CGD available 24/7), too many high-fat insects
Feed CGD every 2-3 days (adults), limit insects to 1x/week, provide climbing exercise

content.content: Temperature Critical for Digestion: Gargoyle geckos require basking temps of 82-85F to properly digest crested gecko diet. If enclosure is too cool (<75F consistently), gecko cannot metabolize food effectively, leading to regurgitation or malnutrition despite eating.
This checklist ensures all critical requirements are met before bringing your gargoyle gecko home.

rows: Minimum size for adult; allows temperature gradient and climbing space
Ventilation + prevents escape (geckos can climb glass)
Provides basking spot at top of enclosure (82-85F)
Adjusts heat output to achieve target temps
Measures surface temps at basking area
12" Arcadia T8 6% OR Zoo Med T8 ReptiSun 5.0 in 14" T8 reflective hood
DIY mix (60% topsoil + 40% coconut fiber) OR Lugarti/Reptisoil
Magnolia, oak, or commercial leaf litter
Bamboo, cork, or mopani wood at multiple heights
Pothos, ferns, bromeliads, or quality fake plants
Pangea, Repashy, or other quality CGD brand
Holds prepared CGD at feeding ledge
Calcium powder without D3 (Arcadia CalciumPro Mg or MinerAll Outdoor)

content.content: Investment Note: Quality gargoyle gecko setup requires $250-400 initial investment. Cutting corners on heating, humidity equipment, or enclosure size compromises welfare. Purchase correct equipment from the start to avoid expensive replacements and vet bills.

Juvenile Enclosure Consideration: Hatchlings and juveniles under 12 grams benefit from smaller temporary "grow out" enclosures (around 5 gallons or 12"x12"x12") until large enough to safely navigate full-sized adult enclosure. Prevents difficulty finding food and reduces stress in very young geckos.
